Abstract: This study investigates the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on household behavior, focusing on consumption patterns, credit utilization, and investment decisions. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset spanning the pandemic period, we analyze how unprecedented economic stimuli and health crises influenced household financial strategies. Our findings reveal significant shifts in consumption towards essential goods and online services, alongside increased savings rates and cautious credit use. Investment behaviors showed a marked preference for safer assets, reflecting heightened risk aversion. The study contributes to the understanding of household finance under extreme conditions, offering insights into the resilience and adaptability of consumer behavior in the face of global crises. These results have implications for policymakers and financial institutions aiming to support economic recovery and stability.
